thread.title: Five players pushing for Wallabies auditions
thread.title_full: Five players pushing for Wallabies auditions

title: Five players pushing for Wallabies auditions
text:
AUS teams fail to aim up 5:41 Super Rugby: Five breakout players giving Wallabies coach Michael Cheika food for thought a minute ago by Christy Doran Source: FOX SPORTS IT’S been a rocky start to the year for Australia’s five Super Rugby franchises. 
Six wins from a 23 matches makes for dire reading in anybody’s books. 
But amongst the doom and gloom from Australia’s underwhelming performances are some rays of sunshine. 
We look at five players who have had a breakout start to the year and will be on Wallabies coach Michael Cheika’s radar. 
Karmichael Hunt (Reds) 
The Reds’ season might be evaporating before their very eyes, but the early season form of Hunt is something to cheer about. 
On the verge of Test selection in 2016, a groin injury stopped Hunt dead in his tracks in the lead up to last June’s three-match Test series against England. 
In truth, his form was hardly spectacular. 
He was still learning the game, still putting on the extra kilograms lost during his stint in AFL and still finding his feet after a turbulent 2015. 
But it seems only injury can derail his Wallabies aspirations this season. 
Hunt issued an early statement at the Brisbane Tens where he took the ball to the line, showcased his silky ball playing skills by putting teammates into holes and hit brutally hard in defence. 
It was those characteristics that defined him as a rugby league player and it’s why Cheika has pushed his name in the past. Karmichael Hunt has been the Reds’ best player in 2017. Source: AAP 
On Sunday against the Jaguares, Hunt was one of a few players in the Reds side who could hold his head high. 
He did let slip a golden opportunity to score late in the second half, but overall he delivered the same robust display which made him a mainstay in Queensland’s State of Origin team. 
With Quade Cooper out suspended, Hunt stood flatter in the line and regularly jumped into the first or second-five position. 
While in defence he was rock solid and was strong over the ball, often arriving at the breakdown before his bigger teammates to keep the Jaguares at bay. 
Israel Folau may have a mortgage on the Wallaby No 15 jersey, but Hunt is applying some pressure on him for the role. 
It’s more likely, however, that the 30-year-old will come into contention for a position on the bench and fill the utility role that Kurtley Beale played, with the latter primed for a return to the midfield. Ryan Louwrens is playing his way into a Wallaby jersey. Source: Getty Images 
Ryan Louwrens (Force) 
New Zealand rugby is doing a lot right at the moment, but one aspect of the game that they’re far ahead of Australia is at scrum-half. 
Not one No 9 playing in Australia would start in any of New Zealand’s five Super Rugby teams. 
Aaron Smith, TJ Perenara and Tawera Kerr-Barlow are world class, Brad Weber is on the sidelines, while Augustine Pulu is elusive, and the Crusaders’ Bryn Hall and Mitchell Drummond are more than respectable. 
All of them are dangerous with the ball and all of them put opposition defences in two minds as to whether they’ll have a snipe, pass or kick. 
At present, this isn’t happening in Australia. Everything is too predictable, too slow. 
French-based Will Genia is head and shoulders Australia’s No 1 scrum-half, but the battle to be his deputy is wide open. 
Nick Phipps and Nick Frisby have gone backwards in 2017, so much so that the former was dropped by his Super Rugby club. 
Nic Stirzaker seems burdened by the Rebels captaincy and needs to stay fit to get back to the heights of 2015, while Wallaby squad member Joe Powell had a tough night against the Highlanders after starting the season in promising touch. 
Force scrum-half Ryan Louwrens is, however, one player putting up his hand for higher honours. 
Like the Force’s season to date, Louwrens is having a go and showing he’s up for the fight after a couple of seasons waiting in the wings. 
Louwrens has a crisp pass, has a good sense of when to run the ball and is one of the better kicking No 9’s in Australia. 
His contest against Pulu this weekend shapes as the key in the Force’s match against the Blues. Tolu Latu is putting pressure on Stephen Moore and Tatafu Polota-Nau Source: News Corp Australia 
Tolu Latu (Waratahs) 
Capped four times for the Wallabies on last year’s Spring Tour, Latu has picked up where he left off last year. 
The Waratahs hooker has been among Australia’s best three players each week since the season started. 
Last year he was the Waratahs’ third choice hooker behind Tatafu Polota-Nau and Hugh Roach. 
But Polota-Nau’s departure to the Force has opened up a starting spot and Latu has grabbed it with both hands. 
While he’s always been strong over the ball, what Latu has done particularly well is improve his workrate across the field and become more consistent at the set-piece. 
No hooker can get away with a dodgy throw and, at present, Latu seems to have honed his skills at the lineout. 
For the time being Wallabies captain Stephen Moore is Australia’s best choice at the hooking role, but at 34 his powers are starting to wane and with a World Cup still more than two years away expect to see Latu rotate with Polota-Nau for the reserve position. Sam Carter is back to his best after a quiet 2016. Source: Getty Images 
Sam Carter (Brumbies) 
A familiar face in Australian rugby, Carter has caught a second wind since being handed the co-captaincy. 
With his fellow co-captain Christian Lealiifano on the comeback from cancer, Carter has been leading the Brumbies and doing a superb job too. 
After the departures of Moore, Matt Toomua, Joe Tomane and the year-long sabbatical of David Pocock, the Brumbies were anticipated to struggle in 2017. 
But instead they lead the Australian conference — albeit with just two wins. 
While it’s still not quite clicking for the Brumbies with ball-in-hand, the leadership and fighting display by the club can’t be questioned and Carter must be credited for his skill in galvanising the young team together. 
Leadership aside, Carter is back to his best in the second row. 
Despite playing 13 Tests for the Wallabies, the 27-year-old has played just two Tests in two years and one of the reasons behind that is he’s struggled to dent the line last year. 
Being a pillar in the lineout is no longer good enough. You have to get over the advantage line and be able to catch and pass. 
A knee injury in 2015 slowed his momentum and it’s only now that he’s back fully fit and firing. Sam Talakai has taken over from scrummaging king Greg Holmes. Source: News Corp Australia 
Sam Talakai (Reds) 
Filling the gap left by Wallaby Greg Holmes was never going to be easy, but Talakai continues to develop as a tight-head prop. 
Holmes was one of the best scrummagers in the country and his exit has been profoundly felt at the Reds. 
After the season-ending injury to James Slipper, Talakai’s muscle in the pack becomes all the more important. 
What we need to see from the front-rower is Talakai carrying the ball forward more. 
While the Kiwis are the best ball-in-hand runners in the world, they also know how to keep it tight, pick and drive and are lightning to the breakdown. 
Notable mentions:
